message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by thiamine deficiency in alcoholics. Small vessel hemorrhage in the mammillary bodies is a common finding in autopsy of patients with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Depigmentation of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson’s disease, widespread atrophy of the cerebral cortex is seen in Alzheimer’s disease, and atrophy of the caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is a result of thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency often seen in alcohol use disorder. Autopsy findings in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome commonly show small vessel hemorrhage in mammillary bodies. Option B refers to Parkinson’s disease, Option C refers to Alzheimer’s disease, and Option D refers to Huntington’s disease, all of which are not related to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of frequent falls, unsteady gait, lateral gaze paralysis, and nystagmus suggest Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency commonly seen in patients with alcohol use disorder. Small vessel hemorrhage in the mammillary bodies is a classic finding of Wernicke encephalopathy. Depigmentation of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, widespread atrophy of the cerebral cortex is seen in Alzheimer's disease, and atrophy of the caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical signs described in the question suggest Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency in patients with alcohol use disorder. Autopsy findings for Wernicke’s encephalopathy typically show small vessel hemorrhage in mammillary bodies. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by thiamine deficiency. Autopsy findings include small vessel hemorrhages in the mammillary bodies of the brain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the wide-based gait and eye examination findings, suggest thiamine deficiency related to alcohol use disorder. The most likely finding on autopsy would be small vessel hemorrhage in the mammillary bodies, which is characteristic of Wernicke encephalopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The findings of the lateral gaze paralysis and horizontal nystagmus suggest Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency. Autopsy will most likely show small vessel hemorrhage in mammillary bodies. Depigmentation of the substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson’s disease, widespread atrophy of cerebral cortex is seen in Alzheimer’s disease, and atrophy of the caudate and putamen is seen in Huntington’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question suggest Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is often caused by thiamine deficiency due to alcohol abuse. Autopsy findings in this condition often show small vessel hemorrhage in the mammillary bodies. Options B, C, and D are associated with other conditions such as Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease, respectively, and are not likely to be seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history indicate Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by thiamine deficiency often due to alcohol use disorder. Autopsy findings typically reveal small vessel hemorrhages in the mammillary bodies. Depigmentation of the substantia nigra suggests Parkinson’s disease, widespread atrophy of cerebral cortex suggests Alzheimer’s disease, and atrophy of the caudate and putamen suggests Huntington’s disease.

Autopsy findings commonly include small vessel hemorrhage in mammillary bodies.
